data.text: Perfect Rain Jacket for Bike Touring / Bikepacking

Trying to find the perfect Rain Jacket. Price is important but don't mind spending for the right gear. Needs to be as light as I can get it, with venting Zips and a hood. Looking at Outdoor Research, Showers Pass, Mont-Bell. Would really like some real world feedback...
I use the same Arc‚Äôteryx Beta SL that I use for feet-packing.
data.author: Scott Rasmussen

data.text: Ummmm,‚Ä¶this might work,‚Ä¶until a good gust of wind blows it up into your face.
data.author: Joe Shunk

data.text: I'm a showers pass fan.
data.author: Phil Metcalfe

data.text: Endura Single Track or Endura MT500
data.author: Lawrence Bailey

data.text: Don't knock the bike poncho, I've used a Brooks on several trips. Great with a tail wind and keep all of you dry. For headwinds I use mountain pass soft shell.
data.author: David Butterly

data.text: I love my showers pass. Use it in cold weather too even if not raining. (I commute to work by bike)
data.author: Deb Young

data.text: Thank you! üòä
data.author: Crockett Ross

data.text: I have a decathlon cycling cape and I love it. It comes touring and commuting.
data.author: Daniel Murphy

data.text: This year on Tour Divide (where we had lots of cold, wet weather) I had Arteryx NORVAN LT HOODY (6.5 oz) and Gore Bike pants (<9 oz) and they worked great. I'd choose that again...

data.text: Perfect thank you!

data.text:

data.author: Kevin Madzia

data.text: I got this one and it just flapped between my knees. No way to attach to handlebars... Also the ‚Äúpockets‚Äù on front is actually the spot your arms come out to the elbows. It was strange but knees were the only thing wet.
data.author: Joseph Long

data.text: I‚Äôve got an Enlightened Equipment rain jacket called the Visp that is amazing! Lightweight, pit zips and a hood.

data.text: Perfect, thank you!

data.text: Showers pass elite is thee best I've come across

data.text: live this. think it'll work in wind?
data.author: Jim Paussa

data.text: Have a look at Ground Effect clothing a New Zealand company. It is quality gear designed and made by people that ride. I have the Storm Trooper and used it for the 3000km Tour Aotearoa and 800km Kopiko.
data.author: Rob Searle

data.text: I just protect my gear and put on the swimming trunks.
data.author: Sam Smith

data.text: Ponchos are good for communting. Not practical for bikepacking. In hot weather, best thing is to be wet from the rain. Mild weather best with a "waterproof" softshell, and for cold wet weather conditions go full goretex.
data.author: Eduardo Guilhon

data.text: I love my OR rain jacket. Doubles as a windbreaker. Breathes but does not let rain in. Hood fits well over my bike helmet.
data.author: Albert Leary

data.text: Which one do you have?
data.author: Crockett Ross

data.text: Honestly, your best bet is to just get wet‚Ä¶ you‚Äôll end up sweating underneath from not getting air circulation and you‚Äôll be gross AND wet. Learn to enjoy the rain and weather, plus your clothes will get clean in the process lol. Just make sure any electronics are in dry bags or something.
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: Good Point, my event will be in February so I was also worried about cold rain..
data.author: Crockett Ross

data.text: Carradice Poncho. Superb. Waxed material on the top which, in my experience, has proved 100% waterproof. Air circulation underneath which means you don‚Äôt sweat, unlike every goretex-style ‚Äòbreathable‚Äô jacket I‚Äôve ever owned. Looks mad but is brilliant in the rain.
data.author: Dave Mitcheson

data.text: I have a jacket by Vaude and it never let me down. Reasonable price, made in Germany. My pants are no name, cheap but all great.
data.author: Julia Cruise

data.text: I like my Poncho

data.author: Crockett Ross

data.text: I would just get a light weight rain jacket then, I‚Äôd probably only use it off the bike anyway if cold isn‚Äôt an issue
data.author: Richard Binks

data.text: I use the OR Helium. It‚Äôs great and super light and packable. It works too. It just doesn‚Äôt have vents.
data.author: Adam Mertz

data.text: Yes, I have been looking at that one specifically
data.author: Crockett Ross

data.text: I use the OR Helium 2 and a f gore shakedry (no hood). The shakedry is an incredible jacket. The breath ability is top notch and you can keep it on and hardly know it‚Äôs there once the rain stops, but it doesn‚Äôt have a hood, can‚Äôt be used with a backpack (not an issue for me), and is fragile. The OR is a great also a great jacket and has all of the things the shakedry doesn‚Äôt except the superior breathability and packs a little bigger.
data.author: Adrian Uttley

data.text: the hood isn‚Äôt a deal breaker I‚Äôll look at the shake dry
data.author: Crockett Ross

data.text: x2 for shakedry
data.author: Dan Reilly

data.text: Cleverhood raincape. Rain capes provide enough air circulation to keep you cool and dry.
data.author: Marc Irwin

data.text: You could get up to all sorts under that rain jacket
data.author: Patrick Gormley

data.text: I have a poncho tarp that can do double duty as rain gear and ultralight shelter. The Gatewood Cape from Six Moons Designs. I used one for a lot of the CDT and got another to do my long bike trip. Sets up with a trekking pole and six stakes and only weighs 11 oz. The price point is good too considering its a shelter.
data.author: Samuel Martinich

data.text:
https://www.sixmoondesigns.com/products/gatewood-cape
Gatewood Cape
sixmoondesigns.com

data.text: Showers pass is a great jacket
data.author: Jock DeBoer

data.text: There is no perfect jacket. If it's hot you sweat, if it's cold. You are cold.
data.author: Kevin Michael

data.text: Just stay home if you're concerned about water. You're out in the elements. This isn't glanmping
data.author: Jake Sehnsucht

data.text: Finisterre have a 50% sale on right now and their rainbird jacket is in it. I have one, it‚Äôs a nice light weight waterproof. The only thing it doesn‚Äôt have are vents under the pits like my old berghaus had but I love it.
data.author: Martyn 'Sete P√©' Walsh

data.text: Fortunately there‚Äôs never any wind when it‚Äôs raining so this thing won‚Äôt flap constantly. It also won‚Äôt act as a sail and blow you off the road. üôÇ
data.author: Jack Kessler

data.text:
The Pearl Izumi Vortex WXB is incredible. They can be found pretty inexpensively these days as they've been discontinued. The breathability is unlike any other waterproof breathable item I've worn. And the feature set is just really on point. I got mine a little big for layering in the winter here in Oregon. Two years later it still works great. Worth every penny. https://www.theclymb.com/product.aspx?p=PZI02599
Pearl Izumi Vortex WxB Hooded Jacket - Men's
theclymb.com
data.author: Caleb Blatz

data.text: yea, i don't think it is possible to stay dry. water is going to get in. just wear a wetsuit and enjoy the cool rain =)
data.author: Todd Stephenson

data.text: My Montebello works well I used it in Oregon in medium downfall for about 2 hours and didn't get wet. Going to test it more this autumn in Washington
data.author: Suzie Roberts

data.text: There‚Äôs a thing called wind that would make the poncho in the pic a bit silly
data.author: Jack Driver

data.text: I actually have something like the poncho in the photo that I got from Decathlon (~$30). It has a few velcro straps in key spots to keep it in position. What I appreciated most about it was that it kept my hands reasonably warm and dry. Can't expect to make good mileage in headwinds, but otherwise it was handy in heavy rain.

data.text: If your commuting you want to get there relatively dry. I've considered something like what you have pictured but always worn a rain suit myself. Get something higher qaulity than those disposable rain suits. I've used them and they work ,but have limited flexibility and don't breath well.

data.text: Castelli RoS with Nano bibs and warmers. It's a system, more than a jacket. You'll never go back.

data.text: thank you !

data.text: At least give it a look. It's pricey as hell. But it'll last a decade and you'll never regret it.
data.author: Mark Hines

data.text: Arcteryx is the best rain jacket I‚Äôve ever had. Had two of them. But even their $250 jacket will Lose its water protection over time. I‚Äôve never had a rain jacket that was 100% WP in a big thunderstorm 2 years after purchase without an aftermarket spray on agent. The longer the pit vents the better and a chest pocket is key!
data.author: Jeff Glessing

data.text: Zpacks Vertice.

data.text: Showers Pass is the best and I own one - but still wet from sweat or wet from rain.

data.text: Goretex is the most waterproof but not as light. Something nylon would be lighter but not very breathable. Always a trade off. I think the OR helium might worth a try
data.author: Dave Mathews

data.text: If you ride in the rain you are going to get wet. All brands mentioned are good. Try something on and make sure it is comfortable to you.
data.author: Phil Rice

data.text: The problem I have is on the pants. After riding with the rain pants, it tends to break down fast with all the rubbing.

data.text: I had something similar when I commuted to work via bike. It is ok for a light rain. Not so much for a downpour but then again nothing is great in that situation.

data.text: That ghost has really long arms...for a ghost.

data.text: Look ma, no legs
data.author: Gary Stoker

data.text: I got nothing much helpful. I‚Äôve never found ‚Äòwaterproof breathable‚Äô that works. I‚Äôm just a soggy mess no matter what. Our man Jan just rides in thick wool, there is wisdom in that. Fortunately here in the west rain is a rare thing. BUT‚Ä¶I must say that I commuted for years in all weather and the Carradice rain cape (waxed canvas) was the bees knees, as long as the bike had fenders. Comfortable, airy, and dry. Love it. Not helpful for bikepacking.
data.author: Neil Doran

data.text: Showers Pass is the only one of the ones you mentioned that makes bike-specific rain jackets? Their Spring Classic would be their lightest. I have three predecessor to it and it's great - it's my daily rain jacket. A goretex shakedry is even lighter / more packable - e.g. a 1985. A frog toggs emergency rain jacket is about equivalent in weight, and way cheaper - if you don't need durability.
data.author: Leif Warner

data.text: It will get caught somewhere,sometimeÔøº!

data.text: Riding in the rain don‚Äòt try to stay dry. Try to stay warm.

data.text: 7mesh Revelation. Fantastic cut, which makes the whole difference, and looks good, even off the bike. Gtx pro, expensive, but recommendable
data.author: Anders Porskrog-Mjelde

data.text: $475 USD for the 7Mesh....What a piss take

data.text: hehe, true. I knew it was pricy but not that bad. Bought mine 2nd hand for nearly nothing. Really good jacket tho
data.author: Anders Porskrog-Mjelde

data.text: if all else fail, then check out Endura. Fairly priced, different options/lines and their house brand shell does really breathe exceptionally well. I‚Äôve done both their road stuff and their burly trail stuff. By far the brand with best value that I‚Äôve encountered.
data.author: Anders Porskrog-Mjelde

data.text: Good to hear. They pop up on sale in my country from time to time but Endura's website is low on information re waterproofness and breathability so I've never taken the plunge.
data.author: Aaron Koolen-Bourke

data.text: Anything Goretex Shakedry is waterproof and very light weight. The penalty is it's a very fragile material.
data.author: Nick Power

data.text: Ponchos are absolutely brilliant. My wife and I have the orange Vaude Valdipinos. Quick to deploy, keep you dry and are very very well ventilated. And good for impromptu Marilyn impressions too!

data.text: Showers Pass rain jacket and rain pants. Amazing thermal insulation in the cold months, yet not too hot in a warm summer rain. I have been using mine for 8 years. Holding up fine. Scrunches down to a tiny light-weight corner in the cargo trailer.

data.text: I have a Vaude poncho which is brilliant for commuting. Protects the top half of my legs pretty good and not sweaty at all unlike jackets. I haven't found it that bad in the wind actually. But it is definitely a low speed bit of kit, the faster you go the wetter you get.
